conclusion: Number of turns in circular coil: N = 200, Area of coil: S = 1 m², Resistance of coil: r = 10 Ω, External resistor: R = 50 Ω, Magnetic field: perpendicular to the coil plane, directed inward, Magnetic induction variation over time: shown in the figure (B/T vs t/s graph)
B increases linearly with time, At t = 3 s, B = 0.4 T
Rate of change: ΔB/Δt = 0.4 T / 3 s = 0.133 T/s
Apply Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction
Induced EMF in the coil: \( \mathcal{E} = -N \cdot S \cdot \frac{dB}{dt} = -200 \cdot 1 \text{ m}^2 \cdot 0.133 \text{ T/s} = -26.67 \text{ V} \)
Negative sign indicates the direction of the induced EMF according to Lenz's law
For power calculations, use the magnitude: 26.67 V
Total resistance in the circuit: \( R_{total} = r + R = 10 \text{ Ω} + 50 \text{ Ω} = 60 \text{ Ω} \)
Current in the circuit: \( I = \frac{\mathcal{E}}{R_{total}} = \frac{26.67 \text{ V}}{60 \text{ Ω}} = 0.4445 \text{ A} \)
Power consumed by resistor R: \( P_R = I^2 \cdot R = (0.4445 \text{ A})^2 \cdot 50 \text{ Ω} = 9.88 \text{ W} \)
Rate of change of the magnetic field is constant throughout the shown time period
Induced EMF and current remain constant, so power consumed by R remains constant at 9.88 W
The maximum power consumed by the external resistor R is 9.88 W
